Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if all notaries installed the identical setup, then a single exploit that worked on that setup kills the notary network

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the white paper explains the general concepts

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: -ac options are what creates runtime forks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: clearly to notarize a chain, you need to run a chain and the destination chain it is notarized to

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: from whitepaper, we know BTC is where KMD notarizes to and i am sure it is explained that assetchains are notarized to KMD

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not sure why this is considered secret information

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if there is a lack of documentation, then plz write it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and @Alright plz give greer/voskcoin a break, it is up to the voters to decide on the issue. if greer is technically capable enough, then the comparison is voskcoins contribution as against someone who is making bounties to get stuff done.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is a fuzzy decision and thus the KMD voters will decide

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @Greer not understanding that -ac options creates a runtime fork and an independent chain, indicates you did not read all the docs

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and instead of bragging how good you are, plz just show us

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: better equipment certainly doesnt hurt, but keep in mind an expert tennis player can use a random piece of wood and beat an amateur using the most expensive equipment

Content: actually plenty of secrets were shared in this channel

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content:
I believe if you update between notarisations you are more likly to do well for the next 24 hours. Also I have seen a reboot on my node did the trick of getting better results. Just my obersations that does not have to be true.
I'm not sure if that is really the reson as in the last 48 hours it did not so good.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as far as i know there are virtually no secrets that have been kept. anybody that claims that is not looking at all the available info, granted there isnt a "notarization for dummies" book. but maybe there shouldnt be

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if there was an official way to do it, then everybody would do it that way and then a single exploit in the official way could be catastrophic

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: When you start the round makes a huge diffrence... One trick is to call each dpow call on iguna with som random delaly of seconds, with lots of chains this does actualyl help (but onyl after restaret) over time it all evens out.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as it is we get a large variety of configurations. I am ok with that, even if the price is a bit longer learning curve.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a lot of times we are confronted with an issue for the first time ever (and many times the only time ever)

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: @CHMEX  I noticed that updates can affect my node performance, don't know if it is true for other people, before the 2nd last update my node performance was really good, then it suddenly fell during the 2nd last update, then after the last update it seems back to normal again

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: writing up documents to cover ever possible scenario... NASA tried to do that, but still the rockets explode

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: better to have problem solvers who can solve whatever problem arises

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as it is not possible to cover every possible case ahead of time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so if getting a stable NN setup is too hard given the docs that exist, then likely some out of the blue event would also not be solved

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: that is a very good point the more different setups and systems are used the more secure it is for the whole network as a single exploit might not work on all system. Mybe at some pint it can run on OSX or even windows....

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: never on windows

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless they rebrand some unix variant

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: windows X

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you sink when thrown in the swimming pool, cant very well be a lifeguard on the oceanfront

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even if there are no instructions given when thrown in the pool

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there certainly wont be instructions on how to deal with an offshore earthquake that happens during a hurricane

Author: mrlynch#5735
Content:
i woke up hoping to find useful tips or hints, instead i spent 1 hr of my life catching up on bitching and moaning that spoon feeding is not available..

as a n00b in kmd and NN i found the NN setup docs to be quite comprehensive, however 'how to run an efficient nn' would be detrimental in my opinion!
as @webworker01 said this is like SF.. kmd knowledge and getting your way around a linux box should be a requirement! running an efficient node is down to commitment, ability & willingness to learn. from the little time i spent here i observed that a NN has tremendous responsibility which should NOT be taken lightly.

if you're not willing to get in everyone's git, go through code, test, break & improve things and dyor one should not be here <- this has nothing to do with current skills btw

@Deleted User - barriers should not be lowered btw, i'd rather we have high standards to which candidates should aspire to.. one should not seek equality of outcome with 0 input.. put some damn hours into it

`and if he is elected, his server will out perform all of yours, just so I can middle_finger you all next year` talk is cheap.. prove it

rant over

Author: Carlos Crypto Economy#7861
Content: OK, I have been reading the conversation about revenue sharings, but I can see that only one approach (the votes buy/sell) has been taken into account. Not everybody offers a revenue share for the same porposes. We wanted to send a message with it saying that we are not in this ellections for profits, as we already own a working infrastructure and after doing some calculations we considered that 50% is enhough for us to mantain the node and thus support the komodo community and its ecosystem.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @Carlos Crypto Economy that is your choice, but dont expect any votes from me

Author: NutellaLicka#4241
Content:
Holy hell, what a day. Turns out I missed one interesting conversation. If I can throw my two cents in there; this time last year I didn't know how to use Linux.... So there's a bit of transparency for any voters considering me as a NN  😛 
A perceived 'lack of docs' didn't stop me learning all I could through trial & error, along with a massive amount of help from multiple members of the community here who put their time and effort into answering my silly questions along with explaining concepts. I wouldn't be able to do a lot, if it wasn't for the patience of people like @Alright @webworker01 @ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢 @blackjok3r , just to name a few. 
I find it difficult to understand when people come into this community and don't find it easy to integrate into. I believe if you have the right attitude and willingness to learn, test, trial, error, and continue to test, you will struggle . I think that could be translated into anything in life though I suppose.
edited for Genies pleasure

Author: Carlos Crypto Economy#7861
Content: @jl777c It is a pity that, the only thing of our message that has penetrated has been that 50% of revenue share. Our intention was to present a proposal as honest as possible, with minimal compensation for our informative work and maintenance of the node. Of course, 50% is not the only thing we offer, as it can be read in our application.
